raw_text:
Moya emotional at Davis Cup win
 
 Carlos Moya described Spain's Davis Cup victory as the highlight of his career after he beat Andy Roddick to end the USA's challenge in Seville.
 
 Moya made up for missing Spain's 2000 victory through injury by beating Roddick 6-2 7-6 (7-1) 7-6 (7-5) to give the hosts an unassailable 3-1 lead. "I have woken up so many nights dreaming of this day," said Moya. "All my energy has been focused on today. "What I have lived today I do not think I will live again." Spain's only other Davis Cup title came two years ago in Valencia, when they beat Australia. And Moya, nicknamed Charly, admitted: "The Davis Cup is my dream and I was a bit nervous at the outset. "Some people have said that I am obsessed but I think that it is better this way. It helps me reach my goals if I am obsessed. "It's really incredible - to get the winning point is really something." Spanish captain Jordi Arrese said: "Charly played a great game. It was his opportunity and he hasn't let us down. "He had lost three times to Roddick, and this was his day to beat him. "He had been waiting years to be in this position." Spain's victory was also remarkable for the performance of Rafael Nadal, who beat Roddick in the opening singles.
 
 Aged 18 years and 185 days, the Mallorcan became the youngest player to win the Davis Cup. "What a great way to finish the year," said Nadal afterwards. US coach Patrick McEnroe wants Roddick and the rest of his team to play more tennis on clay and hone their skills on the surface. "I think it will help these guys even on slow hard courts to learn how to mix things up a little bit and to play a little bit smarter and tactically better." "Obviously it's unrealistic to say that we're going to just start playing constantly on clay, with the schedule. "But certainly I think we can put the work in at the appropriate time and play a couple more events and play against these guys who are the best on this stuff," said McEnroe. Roddick was left frustrated after losing both his singles on the slow clay of Seville's Olympic Stadium. "It's just tough because I felt like I was in it the whole time against one of the top three clay-courters in the world," said the American. "I had my chances and just didn't convert them. The bottom line is they were just better than us this weekend. "They came out, took care of business and they beat us. It's as simple as that."
llama3.2:1b: Carlos Moya described winning Spain's Davis Cup victory over the USA as a highlight of his career after beating Andy Roddick 6-2 7-6 7-6. He made up for missing the previous year's title by overcoming Roddick to secure an unassailable 3-1 lead. The win marked Moya's first Davis Cup victory and he described it as a dream come true. Spain's captain Jordi Arrese praised Moya's performance, saying he played his best game against Roddick. Rafael Nadal also credited Moya with winning the match after beating him in the opening singles.
llama3.2:3b: Carlos Moya described Spain's Davis Cup victory as the highlight of his career after beating Andy Roddick in Seville. Moya made up for missing the 2000 title by winning 6-2 7-6 (7-1) 7-6 (7-5). The win was also notable for Rafael Nadal, who became the youngest player to win the Davis Cup at 18 years and 185 days. US coach Patrick McEnroe wants Roddick's team to practice on clay more, citing it as a key to improvement.
gemma2:2b: Carlos Moya won the Davis Cup for Spain, securing an unassailable 3-1 lead over USA in Seville. He defeated Andy Roddick to win the final point. This victory marks a highlight of Moya's career and was particularly important after missing Spain's previous win in 2000.  Rafael Nadal also contributed significantly to Spain's victory, becoming the youngest player to win the Davis Cup at age 18.  US coach Patrick McEnroe acknowledges the need for his team to focus on playing more on clay, as this would improve their skills and strategy. Roddick, despite fighting hard, acknowledges the superior performance of the Spanish team, losing both singles matches.

Spain's only other Davis Cup title came two years ago when they beat Australia and Moya was described as "charly" due to his strong performance, while Spanish captain Jordi Arrese praised his great game, calling it a "great day." Rafael Nadal, also aged 18 and 185 days, played a key role in Spain's victory, beating Roddick in singles. The defeat was disappointing for US player Andy Roddick, who struggled against Moya on slow clay court surfaces.

This win gave Spain an unassailable 3-1 lead. Moya had missed Spain's previous Davis Cup win in 2000 due to injury and considered the tournament his dream. The victory also showcased Rafael Nadal’s performance as the youngest player to win the Davis Cup at age 18 years and 185 days. US coach Patrick McEnroe acknowledged that playing more clay-based tennis could improve their team's skills, although he noted it would be challenging to play frequently on such surfaces. opencoder:1.5b:
Moya emotional at Davis Cup win

Carlos Moya described Spain's Davis Cup victory as the highlight of his career after he beat Andy Roddick to end the USA's challenge in Seville.

"After he won the USA match, I had a hard time making it. Despite my injuries, I managed to finish the season with an unbeatable lead. I was so overwhelmed when I realized how many more weeks I needed to play to reach the top of the leaderboard. I also didn't miss any match and always stayed consistent." 

Moya made up for missing Spain's 2,000 victory through injury by beating Roddick 6-2 7-6 (7-1) 7-6 (7-5). "I'm always ready to wake up tomorrow to try my best. I think I could have done it better, but I just had the chance." Spain's only other Davis Cup title came two years ago in Valencia, when they beat Australia.

And Moya, nicknamed Charly, admitted: "The Davis Cup is my dream and I was a bit nervous at the outset. I feel so motivated to try and make it this weekend. It helps me reach my goals if I'm obsessed. I think that it's amazing - to get the winning point is really something." 

Spanish captain Jordi Arrese said: "Charly played a great game. He hasn't let us down. He had been waiting years to be in this position." Spain's victory was also remarkable for the performance of Rafael Nadal, who beat Roddick in the opening singles.

Aged 18 years and 185 days, the Mallorcan became the youngest player to win the Davis Cup. "What a great way to finish the year," said Nadal afterwards. US coach Patrick McEnroe wants Roddick and the rest of his team to play more tennis on clay and hone their skills on the surface. "I think it will help these guys even on slow hard courts to learn how to mix things up a little bit and to play a little bit smarter and tactically better." "Obviously it's unrealistic to say that we're going to just start playing constantly on clay, with the schedule. "But certainly I think we can put the work in at the appropriate time and play a couple more events and play against these guys who are the best on this stuff," said McEnroe. Roddick was left frustrated after losing both his singles on the slow clay of Seville's Olympic Stadium.

Carlos Moya won the Davis Cup against Andy Roddick, a moment of personal reflection and recovery after a long injury period. As his 18th winner and youngest champion in history, he shared the honor with others from Spain, setting a new record. Moya had to focus all his efforts on this victory, highlighting his personal growth. Despite three top clay players defeating him before the final, Roderico Nadal performed exceptionally, showcasing his potential for future success. The US team's coach, Patrick McEnroe, emphasizes enhancing performance on clay and surface skills, aiming to build better game strategies. Moya also celebrated finishing a successful year with his victory, reflecting on personal milestones.
tinyllama:1.1b: Achieving a Davis Cup victory at the age of 18 years and 185 days has been described as "the highlight" of Carlos Moya's career by his teammate, who also won the tournament in 2000 with injury. Moya played a dominant match against Andy Roddick to secure Spain's 3-1 lead over the USA in the final match. Despite losing both singles matches on slow clay at the Olympic Stadium in Seville, Roddick was disappointed but accepted that he had been "frustrated" after feeling like he had won the match against a top three clay-court player.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Spanish captain Jordi Arrese, Spanish player Rafael Nadal, and Andy Roddick all expressed their relief at the outcome of Spain's Davis Cup victory over the USA, which Moya called his "highlight of career." In a remarkable display of determination, Moya defeated Andy Roddick 6-2, 7-6, and 7-6 to secure Spain's victory. He admitted that it had been a dream for him to win the title since he was younger, and it gave him an incredible feeling of accomplishment. The Spanish team's victory in Seville was remarkable not just for their win but also for the skills of young players like Rafael Nadal and Andy Roddick, who have shown great improvement on clay. US coach Patrick McEnroe also praised the hard work these players are putting in to become better at tennis, suggesting that they can improve even more on slow surfaces like clay.
